Subject: A few things

There are a few things in the works that some of you may be interested 
in:

1) There is now (once again) a Fortran 90 interface.  So far it is only 
available in the "bleeding edge"  version available for check-out by 
CVS. It currently implements thermo properties, transport properties, 
equilibrium, and kinetic rates for bulk phases, but will soon do the 
same for interfaces. Type 'ctnew -f90' to copy to your directory a demo 
Fortran 90 program and makefile, then simply edit the makefile to 
replace the demo code with your Fortran 90 code.

The basic idea is shown here:

program demo
use cantera
type(phase_t) gas
gas = importPhase('gri30.cti','gri30')
..
nsp = nSpecies(gas)
do i = 1, nsp
    call getSpeciesName(gas, i, name)
    write(*,*) name, moleFraction(gas, i)
end do
...
The procedure calls are very similar to those in the Cantera MATLAB 
interface.  See the demo.f90 program for more things you can do, and 
look at the files in Cantera/fortran/src, particularly 'cantera.f90' 
and 'cantera_xxxx.f90', where 'xxxx' is 'thermo', or 'kinetics', or ...

Documentation is coming soon. This has only been tested so far with NAG 
f95 on Mac and linux systems. Probably the Makefiles will need to  be 
tweaked for other compilers.


2) A new option for specifying reaction rate coefficients will be 
available soon, which will allow specifying sums of Arrhenius terms, 
i.e. kf = sum_n (A_n T^(b_n) exp(-E_n/RT)).  This will hopefully 
eliminate the need to declare duplicate reactions solely to model 
non-Arrhenius behavior


3) I have started a separate CVS module for reaction mechanisms in 
Cantera CTI format.  It only has a few mechanisms so far,  but I plan 
to add more.   Only mechanisms that have been published and validated 
in some manner will be included, and each file contains a citation to 
the paper(s) and possibly web site where it is discussed.  If you have 
a validated, published mechanism you would like to have included in 
this repository, send me either the CTI file, or the Chemkin 
(mechanism+thermo+transport) files, or send me the URL for these.

If you want to check out the repository, do "cvs co reactionmechs" 
using the same CVSROOT you us for anonymous check-out of cantera from 
CVS.  You can also browse the repository via the web by going to the 
Cantera sourceforge site and download individual files.


4) Finally, I am going on vacation for 2 weeks. While I may 
occasionally check e-mail,  it won't be often, and it is likely that 
posts to the user's group will go unanswered (by me at least) for a 
while. This is a good opportunity for other experienced Cantera users 
to step in and answer the questions of new users ...

Dave
